utterances: Just taking a couple of the examples, not mine, but of the Small Business Administration, there's regulations right now that require duplicative background checks for commercial truck drivers.
There's requirements in certain - for example, dentist offices for folks across the board to have a series of training on how to deal with interchange with blood.
The question is, should it apply to the secretary at the front of the office?
I think this will strike the right balance at the agency level, trying to put appropriate incentives.

And when the alternative is an arbitrary regulatory moratorium, I think my more balanced, centrist approach is a way that gets at competitiveness but also gets at the question of trying to strike this balance of where we do need new regulations, making sure that they are still being able to put in place.
Senator Warner, thank you very much for talking with us.
Thank you, Robert.
That's Senator Mark Warner, Democrat of Virginia.
Borzou Daragahi is a reporter for The Los Angeles Times.
He has just returned from Iran and he joins us now from Beirut where he is based.
Welcome to the program.
Thank you so much.
So, as we just heard from Mike Shuster, today's demonstrations were part of the opposition movement.
Remind us what exactly the opposition wants.
Well, you know, it started out wanting to question and have a reconsideration of Iran's June presidential election.
But since the reelection of President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad and the subsequent protests and the crackdown, it does appear that the aims have somewhat changed.
At this point it's not exactly clear what they want.
It's a blood sport in many ways.
They want to damage this government, which they consider a puppet regime that is backed by the Revolutionary Guard and reactionary elements within the Revolutionary Guard.
As the opposition becomes a bit more radicalized, as you say becomes more of blood sport, have they been able to hold on to their broad based support or has the support for the opposition changed?
It seems that the opposition has gained ground in the six months since I've been there.
I was there during the elections and briefly for a few weeks immediately afterward, and it does appear by all measures really that they have gained ground.

That they have expanded their horizons geographically and anyone who goes on Youtube can see that the videotapes of demonstrations that were once only from Teheran and a few other major cities are now all over the country.
In addition, it seems like they have expanded their demographic base.
Now you have many of Iran's ethnic minorities identifying with the movement as well as people who are part of the working class.
A blacksmith came up to me on the street and wanted to talk and say that, you know, we're not just a few people, we are many.
Yet despite what you've been describing there has also been a very powerful crackdown since June on the protestors with trials and imprisonments and lots of reports of police brutality.
Are some people scared by that?
Has that kind of intimidation tactic worked?
Well, I think it's kind of - I mean, it's a Middle East government - my editors always joke: Middle East government tortures dissidents, you know, big surprise.
So, I think that's kind of a dog-bites-man story that there is a crackdown.
I think it was very expected especially since the government considers the green opposition movement a kind of tool of Iran's foreign enemies.

But I think what's most surprising and what the big story of the green movement is, is that the pressure does not seemed to have worked and the traditional tactics of the past, you know, using street tactics to stop protests, hurting people, putting them into prison, having what critics describe as show trials, none of that has really worked and it worked in the past.
And I think that's one of the most extraordinary things we've seen about this green movement.
Some if the traditional tactics aren't working, does the government have other tools up its sleeve, might they try something else?
They could make a deal.
(SOUNDBITE OF LAUGHTER)

I mean, I think that would be the - what many people are kind of confused about and it takes a little bit of analysis about it because it's so obvious that there are so many social forces arrayed against the hard line establishment that's represented by Ahamdinejad.
Why not make a deal with the opposition leaders at least - Mir Hossein Mousavi and Mehdi Karroubi.
And that's one option they have but it doesn't seem like they're moving in the direction of making a deal.
It's often very difficult for people who represent Western news outlets to actually report from Iran.
Now that you've been there, what is it that perhaps people don't know about the country that they should know?
Well, I just think it's really extraordinary how much ordinary life is continuing there and people are going to work.
They're going to their jobs.
They're going to their classes.

But there is this underlying tension as well as the kind of realization that a lot of people have taken on this part- time job of being, you know, activists but, you know, still on the surface, life looks very normal.
You say almost like a part-time job, they take it that seriously?
They spend that much time with it?
Yeah, absolutely, I mean, people who are - and these are not - it's interesting.

They're not your traditional, political types but they see this as important, you know, I'm talking like, you know, a 64-year-old housewife who goes to all the demonstrations and has been beaten and, you know, shows off the place where her bruise on her arm from the last demonstration saying, you know, it's not going stop me from going out.
Borzou Daragahi is a reporter for the Los Angeles Times.
He was speaking to us about his recent trip to Iran.
Thanks so much for being with us.
It's been a pleasure.
This past September, when world leaders descended on New York City for the U.N.
General Assembly meetings, a photographer saw the moment as an opportunity.
He set up a studio just outside the vast General Assembly Hall and tried to convince the most powerful and busiest people in the world to sit for a portrait.
Guidant basically said they're obligated to go through with the deal and that the deal still makes strategic sense in their view.
And this will play out over days, weeks or months.

To fight back against growing sexism, growing violence against women and domestic violence especially, fight back all these politicians who don't move an inch in order to allow women to be in charge and take on responsibilities.

Gruber points out, however, that the majority of Italians now studying in universities are women - a generation she believes won't be passive and might even succeed in breaking down Italy's old boys' network.
Sylvia Poggioli, NPR News, Rome.
Given the high price of gas, many people are choosing to vacation close to home this summer.
And while you'd think that'd be good news for a tourist destination like Atlantic City, which is a short drive from New York, Philadelphia, Washington, D.C., Atlantic City is having a rough year.
Brad Linder reports.
Tourism is the third largest industry in New Jersey.
And a third of all tourist dollars spent in the state are spent in Atlantic City.
The number of cars on the Atlantic City expressway over the July Fourth weekend was up 14 percent this year, but the number of dollars spent at casinos in June was down 11 percent from last year.
I, you know, refer to it as the three-headed monster.
So you've got the, you know, gaming and slot, you've got the down economy, and you've got gas prices.
Jeff Vasser is director of the Atlantic City Convention Center and Visitors Authority.
He says people have less money to spend on leisure, and many people in the region are spending it closer to home.
Pennsylvania and Connecticut are both expanding legalized gambling, which gives people one less reason to hop in a car and make a daytrip to Atlantic City.
Because if somebody simply wants to pull a lever on a slot machine, they're not going to have to go very far from home.
We need to give people a compelling reason to come to Atlantic City.
One casino that's trying to do that is the Borgata.
This summer, the company launched something new: a luxury hotel called the Water Club, which has no casino at all.
Instead, it has fine dining, retail, entertainment and a spa, amenities you won't find at a slots parlor in Pennsylvania.
The one great thing about where we're located is, you know, we have a quarter of the population of the United States sitting within a tank of gas from here.
Larry Mullin is president of the Borgata and Water Club.
We have just not done as a good a job in this Atlantic City marketplace of getting people that have been not coming to this market at all.
Mullin says business has been strong since the resort opened in June.
(Soundbite of bird)
Out on the Atlantic City boardwalk, you can still find plenty of tourists like Joanne Iberra(ph) and Lorenzo Anderson(ph), who drove three hours from the Bronx to get here.
It's nice out here.
People are going to come no matter what, whether the economy's good or the economy's bad.
People have got to get out and enjoy life.
I mean, life is short.
If you don't enjoy it now, you won't be able to enjoy it when you're gone, that's for sure.
But small businessmen like Jim McClain(ph) tell a different story.
McClain runs a souvenir shop on the boardwalk.
He says while casino revenue is down about 11 percent from last year, he's doing half the business he did in 2007.
Are you going to be OK this year?
Oh, I'm going to survive it.
You know, I've been here 37 years.
I'll survive it.
Sure.
But if you had a couple more years like this, what would that mean?
Well, it can't get any worse.
I mean, if it gets worse, I'd have to close up.
You know, if it goes another 10 or 20 percent lower, I'd close it up.
(Soundbite of cash register beeping)
McClain's already laid off four employees this year.
He's manning the store by himself now, but he says it's been easy because there are fewer customers.
Not every industry's been affected the same way by the economic downturn.
One surprising beneficiary: the airlines that fly planes over the shore with banners advertising local and national businesses.
Barbara Tomalino is president of Paramount Air Service in New Jersey.
In a good economy, she says her company does well.
In an economy that's perhaps less than stellar, we do very well.
People are trying to, I guess, be more creative with their advertising dollars.
I don't know if they're using -you know, they're spending more, but they're certainly using it more creatively.
While Paramount Air is spending nearly a $1.50 a gallon more on fuel than it did last year, she says demand has been up so much that the company could actually come out ahead.
